questions.text: Which nerve is responsible for eliciting the corneal reflex during the corneal wisp test? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trigeminal nerve

 

Explanation:


The corneal reflex (also known as the blink reflex) is a protective mechanism that causes involuntary blinking when the cornea is touched. This reflex involves both sensory and motor components. During a corneal wisp test, a cotton wisp or similar object is brought in from the side (to avoid eliciting a visual reflex) and gently touches the cornea.

 

The trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V) serves as the afferent (sensory) pathway for this reflex. Specifically, the ophthalmic division (V1) of the trigeminal nerve carries the sensory information from the cornea when it is stimulated. The sensory information is then processed, and an efferent (motor) response is generated via the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII), which innervates the orbicularis oculi muscle, resulting in the blink.

 

The corneal sensitivity can be tested more precisely using an instrument called an aesthesiometer, which measures the minimal stimulus required to elicit the blink reflex. Corneal sensation is characteristically decreased in viral corneal ulcers, making this test diagnostically valuable.



 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oculomotor nerve: Incorrect. The oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III) is responsible for most eye movements by controlling four of the six extraocular muscles (superior rectus, inferior rectus, medial rectus, and inferior oblique). It also innervates the levator palpebrae superioris muscle (responsible for eyelid elevation) and carries parasympathetic fibers that control pupillary constriction and lens accommodation. It has no role in corneal sensation or the blink reflex pathway.

 

Option C. Abducens nerve: Incorrect. The abducens nerve (cranial nerve VI) innervates the lateral rectus muscle, which is responsible for abduction of the eye (moving the eye outward, away from the nose). It has no sensory function and does not participate in the corneal reflex pathway.

 

Option D. Facial nerve: Incorrect, but partially involved in the reflex arc. While the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) is involved in the corneal reflex, it serves as the efferent (motor) pathway, not the afferent pathway. The facial nerve innervates the orbicularis oculi muscle, which causes the eyelid to close during blinking. The question specifically asks about the nerve responsible for "eliciting" the reflex, which refers to the sensory component (trigeminal nerve), not the motor response.

 

Educational Objective: 


The corneal reflex is mediated by the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V) as the afferent (sensory) pathway and the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) as the efferent (motor) pathway.

questions.text: The provision for the post of ASHA was created under which scheme? [NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) NRHM

 

  • The provision for the post of ASHA (Accredited Social Health Activist) was created under the National Rural Health Mission (NRHM). 
  • NRHM aims to provide accessible, affordable, accountable, effective and reliable primary health care, with ASHA workers serving as a bridge to reduce gaps in rural health care delivery. 
  • Creating a cadre of Accredited Social Health Activists is specifically listed as the first component in NRHM's Plan of Action to Strengthen Infrastructure.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. ICDS (Integrated Child Development Services): ICDS works with Anganwadi Workers (AWWs) and focuses on supplementary nutrition, immunization, health check-ups, referral services, pre-school education, and nutrition & health education for children and mothers. ASHA is not part of the ICDS structure.

 

Option C. RCH (Reproductive and Child Health): The RCH program focuses on maternal and child health services but did not create the provision for ASHAs. RCH was later integrated into the overarching NRHM framework.

 

Option D. None: This is incorrect as ASHA was definitely created under NRHM as part of its core design and implementation strategy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ASHA represents a key innovation of NRHM, designed to serve as the first point of contact between the community and the public health system in rural areas, making healthcare more accessible at the village level.

questions.text: All among the following are clinical features of necrotizing enterocolitis except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metabolic alkalosis

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) is a serious gastrointestinal problem that mostly affects premature infants. It involves infection and inflammation that causes destruction of the bowel (intestine) or part of the bowel.

 

This is not a typical feature of NEC. Instead, NEC can cause metabolic or respiratory acidosis due to the severe infection and inflammation affecting the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Other Options:

 

The typical clinical features of NEC include:

 

Option A. Vomiting: Vomiting is a common symptom in infants with NEC due to gastrointestinal dysfunction.

 

Option B. Abdominal mass: In severe cases, an abdominal mass can be palpated due to distended bowel loops filled with gas or fluid.

 

Option C. Erythema of the abdominal wall: This is seen in advanced stages of NEC, indicating severe inflammation and possible progression to perforation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) can cause metabolic or respiratory acidosis, not metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: Up to what duration of pregnancy is the anti-progesterone compound RU-486 (Mifepristone) effective for inducing abortion? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 63 days

 

In the context of medical termination of pregnancy (MTP), mifepristone (RU-486) is effective for inducing abortion up to 63 days (9 weeks) of pregnancy. The efficacy of the medical method using mifepristone plus misoprostol decreases after 7 weeks, with success rates of 98% up to 7 weeks and dropping to 95% for pregnancies between 7-9 weeks (63 days).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 72 days: This duration (approximately 10 weeks) exceeds the recommended timeframe for mifepristone use in medical abortion. The efficacy significantly decreases beyond 9 weeks.

 

Option C. 88 days: This duration (approximately 12-13 weeks) falls into the second trimester, where medical methods still use mifepristone but with different protocols and dosing regimens than first-trimester procedures.

 

Option D. 120 days: This duration (approximately 17 weeks) is well into the second trimester, where mifepristone may be used but with different protocols and higher risks compared to first-trimester abortions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Mifepristone combined with misoprostol is most effective for medical termination of pregnancy when used within the first 9 weeks (63 days) of pregnancy, with optimal results achieved when used before 7 weeks.

questions.text: In a triage setting, which of the following categories requires the highest priority intervention? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Red

 

In a triage setting, particularly in emergency and disaster scenarios, different colors are used to categorize the urgency of patients' conditions. 

 

This indicates that the patient has life-threatening injuries and requires immediate intervention to save their life. Patients in this category are to be treated first.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Yellow: This signifies that the patient has serious injuries that are not immediately life-threatening. Their treatment can be delayed briefly, but they still need urgent care.

 

Option C. Green: This color is used for patients with minor injuries who are stable enough to wait for a longer period without immediate intervention. These are the "walking wounded."

 

Option D. Black: This category is used for patients who are either deceased or have such extensive injuries that they are not expected to survive given the level of care available. In a mass casualty incident, these patients may be deemed beyond help and may not receive treatment due to limited resources.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In triage, patients categorized as 'Red' require the highest priority intervention due to the life-threatening nature of their injuries and the necessity of immediate treatment to save their lives.

questions.text: A group of 20 friends kept partying till late at night. Two of them ate pastries from outside. They present with nausea and vomiting in the early morning. What is the most likely causative agent implicated? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Enterotoxin of Staphylococcus

 

The most likely causative agent in the given scenario is enterotoxin of Staphylococcus aureus. It causes food poisoning within 30 minutes to 6 hours after consumption of the contaminated food.

 

The common sources of infection are the foods that are not cooked after handling. These include sliced meats, puddings, pastries, and sandwiches. Patients present with nausea, vomiting, stomach cramps, and diarrhea.

 

Food poisoning is caused by enterotoxin produced by S. aureus. It is a preformed toxin that is relatively heat stable while most of the other exotoxins are heat-labile. It stimulates the vagus nerve and vomiting center of the brain and also stimulates intestinal peristaltic activity. Eight antigenic types of enterotoxin are currently known of which is Type A toxin is responsible for most cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Emetic toxin of B. cereus: Food poisoning after consumption of fried rice or chinese street food is strongly suggestive of Bacillus cereus (Serotypes 1, 3, 5). Two mechanisms of action have been described for the enterotoxin of B. cereus, one involving stimulation of the cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) system and the other independent of it. Food poisoning after eating food contaminated with Bacillus cereus is of two types, namely diarrheal type and emetic type, caused by an enterotoxin and an emetic toxin respectively.

 

Option C. Verocytotoxin from E. coli: Associated with a different set of symptoms primarily involving severe abdominal cramps and bloody diarrhea, not rapid-onset vomiting.

 

Option D. Shiga toxin from Shigella: Causes dysentery, which is characterized by fever, abdominal pain, and bloody diarrhea, not primarily vomiting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The enterotoxin of Staphylococcus aureus can cause rapid-onset food poisoning characterized by nausea and vomiting, typically within hours after consuming contaminated food such as pastries. Remembering the association between specific foods and pathogens can aid in prompt diagnosis and management.

questions.text: Which characteristic best describes an ideal therapeutic radioisotope for medical use? (NEET Pg 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Strong Beta; Low Gamma emitter

 

An ideal therapeutic radioisotope should be a strong beta emitter with low gamma emission. Beta particles have relatively high energy and are strongly absorbed by adjacent tissue, allowing them to cause substantial damage to targeted cells (like cancer cells). Low gamma emission is preferred to minimize radiation exposure to surrounding healthy tissues and healthcare workers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Strong Beta; Strong Gamma emitter - While the strong beta emission is desirable for therapy, strong gamma emission is problematic because gamma rays penetrate deeply through tissue and beyond the patient's body, potentially causing unwanted radiation exposure to healthy tissues and medical personnel.

 

Option C. Low Beta; Low Gamma emitter - Low beta emission would provide insufficient therapeutic effect for treating conditions like cancer that require substantial radiation damage to abnormal cells. The radiation would be too weak to effectively destroy target tissues.

 

Option D. Low Beta; Strong Gamma emitter - This is the worst combination for therapy. The low beta emission provides insufficient therapeutic effect, while the strong gamma emission causes unnecessary radiation exposure to surrounding tissues and medical personnel.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Therapeutic radioisotopes ideally emit strong beta particles to deliver localized cell damage with minimal gamma radiation to protect surrounding tissues and healthcare providers.

questions.text: Mr. Seth recently underwent surgery to remove a parathyroid gland due to hyperparathyroidism. The surgeon informed the patient that one or more of the parathyroid glands may be transferred to another location during the surgery to protect them or due to their location. The parathyroid is commonly transferred to? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Brachioradialis

 

Explanation:

 

The most common site for the relocation of the parathyroid gland(s) is in the forearm muscle, specifically the nondominant side brachioradialis. Transplantation to this location provides several advantages:

  • Accessibility: The forearm location is easily accessible for potential future surgical interventions if necessary.
  • Monitoring: This location allows for straightforward monitoring of parathyroid function using simple clinical tests.
  • Functionality: The transplanted gland(s) will continue to produce parathyroid hormone normally, aiding in the regulation of calcium levels in the body.
  • Ease of Removal: If there is disease recurrence after surgery, the forearm location facilitates easy removal.
  • Typically, a total of 12 to 14 pieces are transplanted in a type of heterotopic transplant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Triceps: Triceps is not a preferred site for parathyroid transplantation due to less accessibility and monitoring challenges compared to the brachioradialis.

 

Option B. Biceps: Biceps is also not commonly used for parathyroid transplantation because it does not offer the same ease of access and monitoring advantages as the brachioradialis.

 

Option C. Sartorius: Sartorius is not a preferred site for parathyroid transplantation. The forearm muscle (brachioradialis) is favored for its convenience and monitoring benefits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The brachioradialis muscle in the forearm is the most common site for parathyroid gland relocation during surgery due to its ease of access, convenient monitoring, and straightforward removal if needed.

questions.text: The marked line corresponds to which vertebral level? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. L3

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a diagram with a line indicating the subcostal plane, which corresponds to a specific vertebral level. The subcostal plane is an important anatomical landmark and is used to divide the abdomen into regions for clinical and surgical purposes.

 

  1. Subcostal Plane: The subcostal plane passes through the lowest point of the costal margin, which is generally at the level of the third lumbar vertebra (L3).
  2. Anatomical Landmarks:
    • The subcostal plane is a horizontal plane that typically lies just below the rib cage.
    • It is an important reference point for dividing the abdomen into regions.
    • The umbilicus, lies at the level of the L3-L4 junction, but the subcostal plane is typically slightly superior to this and corresponds to L3.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T12: This is incorrect. T12 is located higher up in the thoracic region.

 

Option B. L1: This is incorrect. The transpyloric plane, passes through the level of L1.

 

Option C. L2: This is incorrect. L2 is also superior to the subcostal plane.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The subcostal plane is an important anatomical landmark that typically corresponds to the level of the third lumbar vertebra (L3), helping to divide the abdomen into regions for clinical and surgical reference.

questions.text: Preferable time for IUCD insertion in a 28-year-old woman who has just delivered a healthy newborn. It was a normal vaginal delivery. [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Up to 48 hours

 

Intrauterine Contraceptive Device (IUCD) insertion timing can be categorized into three main periods:

 

  1. During Menstruation: IUCD insertion during menstruation is preferred within the first 10 days of the menstrual cycle to ensure the woman is not pregnant and to ease insertion due to the open cervical os.
  2. Immediate Postpartum: The best time for postpartum IUCD insertion is within the first 48 hours after delivery. If not done within this window, insertion can be performed up to 1 week postpartum. This timing is optimal as the cervix is dilated, and there is a reduced risk of expulsion compared to later periods.
  3. Post Puerperal: If IUCD insertion is not performed immediately postpartum, the next preferred timing is 6 to 8 weeks after delivery when the uterus has involuted and stabilized.

 

For this question, since the woman has just delivered, the most precise and preferred time is within the first 48 hours postpartum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most preferable time for IUCD insertion after a normal vaginal delivery is within the first 48 hours postpartum to take advantage of the naturally dilated cervix and minimize expulsion risk

questions.text: Which of the following psychological coping strategies is not considered a defense mechanism? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Replacement

 

Defense mechanisms are unconscious psychological strategies used by individuals to cope with reality and maintain self-image. Among the options provided, rationalization, displacement, and regression are well-known defense mechanisms.

 

However, Replacement is not considered a recognized psychological defense mechanism. The term "replacement" might refer to various coping strategies or processes, but it is not classified as a defense mechanism in psychological theory.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rationalization: This is a defense mechanism where individuals create a seemingly logical reason for irrational or unacceptable behaviors or feelings to avoid the true explanation.

 

Option B. Displacement: This defense mechanism allows a person to transfer feelings or reactions from the original object or person to a safer substitute. For example, someone angry at their boss might instead take out their frustration on a family member.

 

Option C. Regression: This occurs when an individual faced with stress retreats to an earlier developmental stage. For instance, an adult under stress might start behaving like a child, engaging in activities or behaviors typical of a younger age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

"Replacement" is not classified as a defense mechanism, whereas rationalization, displacement, and regression are recognized defense mechanisms used to protect oneself from anxiety or unacceptable impulses.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1) syndrome presents with symptoms suggestive of a gastrinoma. Which of the following is the most common site of occurrence in MEN 1 syndrome? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Duodenum

 

Explanation:

 

In patients with Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1) syndrome, gastrinomas are most commonly located in the duodenum. Gastrinomas are the most common functional pancreatic endocrine tumors associated with MEN 1 and are often found in the first and second parts of the duodenum.

 

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1) Overview:

 

  • MEN 1 is a genetic disorder that primarily affects the endocrine glands, leading to the development of multiple endocrine tumors.
  • The main features of MEN 1 include:
    • Parathyroid tumors: These cause hyperparathyroidism, the most common feature of MEN 1.
    • Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (NETs): These tumors can be functional (producing hormones) or non-functional. Functional NETs include gastrinomas, insulinomas (causing hypoglycemia), glucagonomas, and VIPomas.
    • Pituitary tumors: These are usually benign but can secrete various hormones, leading to different clinical manifestations such as prolactinomas, growth hormone-secreting tumors (acromegaly), and ACTH-secreting tumors (Cushing's disease).

 

Gastrinoma and Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome:

 

  • Gastrinomas are associated with increased gastric acid production and can lead to Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, characterized by severe peptic ulcers and gastrin overproduction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Jejunum: Gastrinomas are less commonly found in the jejunum compared to the duodenum in MEN 1 syndrome.

 

Option B. Ileum: The ileum is not a common site for gastrinomas in MEN 1 syndrome. The duodenum is the primary site.

 

Option D. Stomach: While gastrinomas can theoretically occur in the stomach, they are most commonly found in the duodenum in patients with MEN 1 syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In MEN 1 syndrome, gastrinomas are most commonly located in the duodenum. They are the most frequent functional pancreatic endocrine tumors associated with this genetic disorder.

questions.text: Which bacterium is typically described as club-shaped? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Diphtheria

 

Explanation:

 

Corynebacterium diphtheriae, the causative agent of diphtheria, is typically described as club-shaped. The very name "Corynebacterium" derives from the Greek word "coryne" meaning "club." These bacteria have a characteristic morphology showing swollen ends that give them a club-shaped appearance. They also display a distinctive arrangement described as "Chinese letter" or "cuneiform" formation, where bacterial cells tend to lie at acute angles to each other due to their snapping type of division.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumococci - Pneumococci (Streptococcus pneumoniae) are described as "flame-shaped" or "lanceolate" diplococci, not club-shaped. They typically appear as pairs of cocci with pointed ends facing outward, resembling a flame or lance shape. They may be encapsulated and are Gram-positive organisms.

 

Option C. Gonococci - Gonococci (Neisseria gonorrhoeae) are described as "kidney-shaped" or "bean-shaped" diplococci with adjacent sides concave, not club-shaped. They are Gram-negative diplococci that typically appear in pairs with their flat or concave sides facing each other.

 

Option D. V. Cholera - Vibrio cholerae is described as "curved, comma-shaped" Gram-negative bacilli, not club-shaped. These bacteria are curved rods with a single polar flagellum that gives them their characteristic "darting" motility. They do not exhibit the club-shaped morphology seen with Corynebacterium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Corynebacterium diphtheriae displays a distinctive club-shaped morphology with swollen ends and forms characteristic arrangements described as "Chinese letter" or "cuneiform" patterns due to their unique snapping division, which is a key microscopic feature for identification.

questions.text: The "Money Bag" appearance of the heart on a chest X-ray is most commonly associated with: (NEET Pg 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Pericardial Effusion

 

Explanation: 

 

The "Money Bag" appearance of the heart on a chest X-ray is a classic radiographic finding characterized by an enlarged, globular cardiac silhouette. This distinctive appearance occurs when fluid accumulates in the pericardial space, causing the heart to take on a rounded shape. The cardiac enlargement is typically symmetric and may obscure normal cardiac contours, resembling a money bag.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tetralogy of Fallot - This congenital heart defect typically shows a "boot-shaped" heart (coeur en sabot) on chest X-ray due to right ventricular hypertrophy and a small pulmonary artery, not a money bag appearance.

 

Option B. TAPVC (Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection) - This condition usually presents with a "snowman" or "figure-of-8" appearance (supracardiac type) or cardiomegaly with pulmonary venous congestion, not a money bag appearance.

 

Option D. Emphysema - In emphysema, the heart typically appears small and vertical (referred to as a "hanging heart" or "drop heart") due to hyperinflation of the lungs. This is the opposite of the enlarged, rounded appearance seen in pericardial effusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "Money Bag" appearance on chest X-ray represents a globular cardiac silhouette caused by pericardial effusion where fluid accumulation creates a rounded, enlarged cardiac shadow with smooth margins.

choices.text: Transducers produce waves by piezoelectric effect
Transducers receive waves by reverse piezoelectric effect
Lead Zirconate Titanate (PZT) has marked piezoelectric effect

questions.text: All of the following statements about the Piezoelectric Effect are true, except:(NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Used in USG and MRI

 

Explanation: 

 

The piezoelectric effect is used in ultrasound imaging but is not used in MRI. MRI relies on the principles of nuclear magnetic resonance, using a strong magnetic field and radiofrequency pulses to generate images, completely different from the piezoelectric principles. Piezoelectric crystals in transducers are the fundamental components that enable ultrasound imaging by converting electrical energy to sound waves and vice versa.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Transducers produce waves by piezoelectric effect - CORRECT statement. Ultrasound transducers use piezoelectric crystals (specifically PZT) to convert electrical energy into mechanical (sound) waves through the piezoelectric effect.

 

Option C. Transducers receive waves by reverse piezoelectric effect - CORRECT statement. When ultrasound waves return to the transducer, they cause the piezoelectric crystals to vibrate, converting mechanical energy back into electrical signals through the reverse piezoelectric effect.

 

Option D. Lead Zirconate Titanate (PZT) has marked piezoelectric effect - CORRECT statement. PZT is the material used for piezoelectric crystals in ultrasound transducers precisely because of its strong piezoelectric properties.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The piezoelectric effect is fundamental to ultrasound imaging technology through both the generation of sound waves and the reception of echoes, but has no role in MRI technology which operates on completely different physical principles.

choices.text: Descent, engagement, internal rotation, flexion, external rotation
Descent, engagement, internal rotation, flexion, external rotation+
Engagement, Descent, Flexion, Internal, Rotation, Extension, External Rotation, Expulsion
Engagement, descent, external rotation, internal rotation, flexion

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct order of the cardinal movements of labor? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Engagement, Descent, Flexion, Internal Rotation, Extension, External Rotation, Expulsion

 

The cardinal movements of labor follow a specific sequence that allows the fetus to navigate through the maternal pelvis. These movements begin with engagement when the biparietal diameter crosses the pelvic brim, followed by descent which is a continuous process facilitated by myometrial pressure, bearing down efforts, and fetal body extension. Flexion reduces the presenting diameter from 11.5 cm (occipitofrontal) to 9.5 cm (suboccipitobregmatic). Internal rotation then occurs at the pelvic floor, followed by extension for delivery of the head. After the head delivers, restitution and external rotation occur to align the head with the shoulders, followed by expulsion of the shoulders and trunk.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Descent, engagement, internal rotation, flexion, external rotation: This sequence is incorrect because engagement precedes descent in normal labor. Additionally, this option is missing extension and expulsion, which are critical parts of the delivery process.

 

Option B. Descent, engagement, internal rotation, flexion, external rotation+: Similar to option A, this incorrectly places descent before engagement. The correct understanding is that the fetal head must engage before continued descent can occur.

 

Option D. Engagement, descent, external rotation, internal rotation, flexion: This sequence incorrectly places external rotation before internal rotation. External rotation follows the delivery of the head and represents alignment of the head with the shoulders, while internal rotation occurs within the pelvis before the head delivers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cardinal movements of labor follow the sequence best remembered by the mnemonic "Every Engagement, Darn Descent, Fool Flexion, In Internal rotation, Egypt Extension, Royally Restitution, Eats External rotation, Eggs Expulsion," which ensures proper navigation of the fetus through the birth canal.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with seizures. On further evaluation, there was also a history suggestive of manic and depressive episodes. Which of the following drugs should be prescribed?  (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Valproate

 

The patient has a history of both seizures and bipolar disorder, characterized by manic and depressive episodes. Valproate (also known as valproic acid) is an anticonvulsant medication that is effective in treating both seizure disorders and bipolar disorder. It helps in stabilizing mood and preventing both manic and depressive episodes, making it an appropriate choice for patients with comorbid bipolar disorder and seizures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pregabalin: This drug is primarily used for neuropathic pain and certain anxiety disorders; it is not effective in the treatment of bipolar disorder.

 

Option C. Phenytoin: This is an anticonvulsant used to treat seizures but does not have mood-stabilizing properties needed for bipolar disorder.

 

Option D. Levodopa: This is primarily used in the treatment of Parkinson's disease and has no role in the management of seizures or bipolar disorder.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Valproate is effective for treating both seizure disorders and bipolar disorder, making it the drug of choice for patients with comorbid conditions.

questions.text: An infant is brought by his parents with complaints that his urine turns black on standing. Which of the following metabolic disorders is likely? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alkaptonuria

 

OPTION B: Blackening of urine on standing is characteristic feature of alkaptonuria.

 

Other Options:

 

 

Educational objective:

questions.text: A 56-year-old male recently diagnosed with renal cell carcinoma, with imaging indicating a tumor size less than 4 cm, what would be the most suitable initial treatment approach for this patient's condition among the following options? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Partial nephrectomy

 

For tumors less than 4 cm, the recommended procedure is a partial nephrectomy, also known as nephron-sparing surgery.

 

  • This procedure involves removing the tumor and a small margin of healthy tissue surrounding it while leaving the remainder of the kidney intact. It is the recommended treatment for smaller renal tumors, typically less than 4 cm in diameter (Stage T1a tumors). For the 56-year-old patient with a renal tumor less than 4 cm, partial nephrectomy is the preferred initial treatment approach as it aims to treat the cancer while preserving as much kidney function as possible.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Partial nephrectomy + neoadjuvant chemotherapy: Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is generally resistant to chemotherapy, making this option less relevant for the patient's situation given the size of the tumor.

 

Option C. Radical nephrectomy: This procedure involves the removal of the entire affected kidney, the adrenal gland above the kidney, surrounding fatty tissue, and sometimes nearby lymph nodes. It is the preferred treatment for larger tumors or those that have started to spread outside the kidney. For a tumor less than 4 cm, and with no indication of it having spread, a radical nephrectomy may be more aggressive than necessary.

 

Option D. Radical nephrectomy + postoperative radiotherapy: Renal cell carcinomas are resistant to radiotherapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Partial nephrectomy is the recommended initial treatment for renal cell carcinoma tumors less than 4 cm in diameter (Stage T1a), as it aims to remove the tumor while preserving as much kidney function as possible. This approach balances oncological control with the preservation of renal function.

questions.text: Which of the following causes unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gilbert syndrome

 

Gilbert syndrome is a common hereditary condition characterized by mild unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. This condition arises due to a partial deficiency of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase, which is responsible for conjugating bilirubin in the liver. As a result, there is an accumulation of unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin in the bloodstream. Patients with Gilbert syndrome often have normal liver function tests and no significant liver pathology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rotor syndrome:  This is a rare hereditary condition that causes conjugated (direct) hyperbilirubinemia due to defects in hepatic storage and excretion of conjugated bilirubin.

 

Option C. Dubin Johnson syndrome: Another hereditary condition that leads to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, characterized by a defect in the excretion of conjugated bilirubin into the bile ducts. The liver cells appear darkly pigmented due to the accumulation of a pigment similar to melanin.

 

Option D. Primary biliary cholangitis: This is an autoimmune disease that causes destruction of the small bile ducts in the liver, leading to cholestasis and conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It is associated with elevated alkaline phosphatase levels and the presence of antimitochondrial antibodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gilbert syndrome causes unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to a partial deficiency of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase, whereas Rotor syndrome, Dubin Johnson syndrome, and primary biliary cholangitis cause conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

questions.text: Which JAK inhibitor drug is recommended for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis in a patient who is not responding well to TNF-alpha blockers? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tofacitinib

 

Tofacitinib is a JAK (Janus Kinase) inhibitor that is specifically approved for treating moderate to severe ulcerative colitis in patients who have failed or are not responding to TNF-alpha blockers. It represents a different mechanism of action compared to TNF-alpha inhibitors, making it a suitable alternative for patients who have failed anti-TNF therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ustekinumab: Incorrect. While it can be used in inflammatory bowel disease, it is a combined anti-IL-12 and IL-23 blocker, not a JAK inhibitor.

 

Option B. Etanercept: Incorrect. This is an anti-TNF drug, and the question specifically asks about patients who are not responding to TNF-alpha blockers.

 

Option C. Vedolizumab: Incorrect. This is an 47 integrin blocker used in IBD, but not a JAK inhibitor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tofacitinib is the JAK inhibitor approved for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis in patients who have failed TNF-alpha blockers. Other JAK inhibitors used in rheumatological diseases include baricitinib and upadacitinib.

choices.text: Increases the risk of malignant hyperthermia

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of Total Intra-Venous Anesthesia (TIVA)? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reduces cerebral metabolic rate

 

Propofol, the primary induction agent used in TIVA, decreases cerebral metabolic rate (CMR), cerebral blood flow (CBF), and intracranial tension (ICT). These effects make propofol especially advantageous for neurosurgical procedures. When combined with remifentanil, it offers excellent hemodynamic stability and rapid recovery due to their short elimination half-lives. This combination makes TIVA particularly suitable for day-care surgeries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Causes increased renal toxicity: Propofol does not cause significant renal toxicity. It is primarily metabolized in the liver, with about 30% extrahepatic metabolism occurring in the kidneys and lungs. Its metabolites are inactive and do not accumulate to cause toxicity.

 

Option C. Increases the risk of malignant hyperthermia: Propofol is actually the induction agent of choice in patients susceptible to malignant hyperthermia, as it does not trigger this condition.

 

Option D. Inhibits hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction: This effect is more commonly associated with volatile anesthetic agents. Propofol has minimal impact on hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction compared to inhalational agents.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Total Intravenous Anesthesia (TIVA) using propofol and remifentanil reduces cerebral metabolic rate, provides stable hemodynamics, enables quick recovery, and is ideal for both neurosurgical and day-care surgical procedures.

questions.text: Which of the following drug used in ADHD is a Selective Norepinephrine Reuptake Inhibitor? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Reboxetine

  

Reboxetine is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (NRI) primarily used as an antidepressant. It selectively inhibits the reuptake of norepinephrine, enhancing its concentration in the synaptic cleft, which is beneficial in treating ADHD symptoms. Although it is not commonly used as a first-line treatment for ADHD, it can be prescribed off-label in certain cases due to its mechanism of action targeting norepinephrine, which plays a significant role in attention and impulse control.

 

Note Atomoxetine is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI), used in treating ADHD, but not mentioned in option.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Modafinil: Modafinil is a stimulant that promotes wakefulness and is used primarily for conditions like narcolepsy and sleep disorders. It is not a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor and works mainly by influencing dopamine pathways, making it unsuitable as an answer.

 

Option C. Methylphenidate: Methylphenidate is a central nervous system stimulant commonly used to treat ADHD, but it works primarily by inhibiting the reuptake of dopamine and norepinephrine rather than selectively targeting norepinephrine alone.

 

Option D. Guanfacine: Guanfacine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist used in the treatment of ADHD. It does not inhibit norepinephrine reuptake but instead works by stimulating alpha-2 receptors, which reduces sympathetic nerve impulses, leading to a calming effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reboxetine is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (NRI) that can be used off-label for ADHD, distinct from other ADHD medications that target both norepinephrine and dopamine or act on other neurotransmitter systems.

choices.text: Jaundice less than 7 days before development of encephalopathy

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with Wilson's disease is being considered for liver transplantation. According to King's College Criteria for predicting mortality in Acute Liver Failure (ALF), which of the following is not included?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Jaundice less than 7 days before development of encephalopathy

 

Explanation: 

 

King's College Criteria are widely used to predict mortality in patients with acute liver failure and identify those who may require urgent liver transplantation.

 

Jaundice less than 7 days before development of encephalopathy: According to the King's College Criteria for non-paracetamol causes, a duration of jaundice before the onset of encephalopathy greater than 7 days (not less than 7 days) is one of the parameters that might indicate the need for liver transplantation. If the encephalopathy develops rapidly after the onset of jaundice (i.e., within 7 days), it suggests a more acute and potentially reversible cause, such as acute viral hepatitis, which might recover without transplantation.

 

Given the information, the incorrect parameter in the King's College criteria for transplantation, would be "Jaundice less than 7 days before development of encephalopathy" (Option D).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Age <10 years: Age is a factor in the King's College Criteria for non-paracetamol-induced liver failure. Children aged less than 10 years are considered at higher risk and this age group may be included in the criteria for transplantation.

 

Option B. PT >100s: Prothrombin time (PT) reflects the liver's ability to synthesize clotting factors. A greatly prolonged PT (>100 seconds) is an indication of severe liver dysfunction and is one of the King's College Criteria for both paracetamol and non-paracetamol-induced liver failure as a potential requirement for liver transplantation.

 

Option C. Bilirubin >300 mol/L: An elevated bilirubin level indicates significant liver dysfunction. A bilirubin level greater than 300 mol/L is one of the King's College Criteria for non-paracetamol-induced liver failure and suggests that liver transplantation may be necessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

King's College Criteria for liver transplantation in acute liver failure include specific parameters such as prolonged PT, elevated bilirubin, and specific age groups. The duration of jaundice before the development of encephalopathy is significant if it exceeds 7 days. Jaundice for less than 7 days is not a parameter for transplantation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with vaginal bleeding. A transvaginal ultrasound reveals an endometrial thickness of 8.0 mm. What should be the next step in management? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Histopathological examination of curettage

 

In postmenopausal women with vaginal bleeding, endometrial thickness >5mm on transvaginal ultrasound warrants histopathological examination to exclude malignancy. The evaluation algorithm for postmenopausal bleeding specifically indicates that endometrial biopsy is necessary when endometrial thickness exceeds 5mm. This patient's endometrial thickness is 8mm, which exceeds this threshold and necessitates tissue sampling to rule out endometrial hyperplasia or carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hysterectomy: This is too aggressive as an initial step. Hysterectomy should only be considered after histopathological confirmation of malignancy or in cases of complex hyperplasia with atypia that has a 29% risk of progression to cancer. The diagnostic workup must be completed first.

 

Option B. Begin progesterone therapy: Treatment cannot begin without a tissue diagnosis. Progesterone therapy is appropriate for certain types of endometrial hyperplasia, but diagnosis must precede treatment. Different types of hyperplasia have different management approaches based on their risk of progression to cancer.

 

Option D. Follow-up sonography: This would be appropriate if the endometrial thickness was <5mm. Since the thickness is 8mm, which exceeds the 5mm threshold for postmenopausal women with bleeding, immediate histopathological examination is indicated rather than follow-up imaging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In postmenopausal bleeding, endometrial thickness >5mm on transvaginal ultrasound necessitates histopathological examination to rule out endometrial malignancy, regardless of other clinical factors.
